Expectation1: Perform assigned physical tasks and material handling efficiently.
Situation1: A carpenter is waiting for you to bring them the next load of lumber so they can continue their work without interruption.
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: The community study circle convenes tonight to discuss verses the person has not yet read.
Story: I wiped the sweat from my brow as I hurried across the site, the weight of the lumber digging into my shoulder. The carpenter waved, impatience clear in his stance—he needed this load to keep the project moving. My foreman’s words echoed in my mind: “No delays, everyone’s counting on you.” I wanted to do my job well, to be reliable, to not let the team down. But as I stacked the boards, my phone buzzed with a reminder: the community study circle was tonight. I hadn’t read the assigned verses from the Quran yet. I was supposed to recite and reflect, to come prepared and contribute. My brothers and sisters in faith would expect me to be ready, to show respect for the words of Allah. I felt the pressure mounting from both sides—my hands rough from labor, my heart heavy with guilt. I glanced at the clock, torn between the demands of my work and the expectations of my faith, unsure which duty I could afford to let down.
